questions.question: A process is controlled by a program.
A program is a set of instructions that specify the operations, data, and the control sequence.
An instruction is stored in binary code that specifies a sequence of microoperations.
Instruction codes together with data are stored in memory.
The purpose of Chapter 5 is to introduce a basic computer and show how its operation can be specified with register transfer statements.
Instruction Code is a group of bits that instructs the computer to perform a specific operation.
The basic part of the Instruction Code is the address part.
A group of bits in the Instruction Code can define operations such as add, subtract, multiply, shift, and complement.
Instruction code format consists of three parts: Op. Code, Address, and Data.
Op. Code specifies 16 possible operations.
The address field in an instruction is always 12 bits.
If an operation does not need an operand from memory, the address field can be used for other purposes.
Immediate operand addressing specifies the operand directly in the instruction.
Direct operand addressing specifies the address of the operand in the instruction.
The instruction code always includes an address field.
In indirect addressing, the bits in the second part of the instruction designate an address of a memory word where the operand's address is found.
A direct address is indicated when I=1 in the instruction code.
The effective address (EA) can be directly used without modification to access an operand.
Indirect addressing is indicated when I=0 in the instruction code.
The opcode for a branch-type instruction is always located at the beginning of the instruction format.
The operand '457' in the instruction 'ADD 457' refers to a direct address.
The instruction 'ADD R1, R2, R3' places the result of R2 + R3 into R1.
The instruction 'ADD 300' uses an indirect address for the operand.
The opcode 'ADD' specifies that the operation is to subtract values.
The instruction format includes only the opcode and the address.
The operand '1350' in the instruction 'ADD 1350' refers to an indirect address.
The HALT instruction requires operands.
The NOT R4 instruction uses one operand.
The ADD R1, R2 instruction uses three operands.
The ADD R1, R2, R3 instruction uses three operands.
The MADD R4, R1, R2, R3 instruction uses more than three operands.
An instruction can contain an opcode and immediate operand.
An instruction can contain an opcode and the address of data using direct addressing.
Indirect addressing involves an address where the address of the data is found.
An opcode can be part of a register-reference or input/output instruction.
The basic computer instructions are stored in the Program Counter.
The size of each memory word in the basic computer is 16 bits.
Each instruction in the basic computer occupies one word.
The address register is connected to the memory.
The Program Counter increments by units of 2.
Does the Program Counter point to the next address of the program?
Does the Operand Part contain the address of needed data in direct addressing?
Is the address part of IR placed on the bus and loaded back into the AR in indirect addressing?
Indirect addressing occurs when the operand contains the address of the address of needed data.
Direct addressing involves using the address of the address of needed data.
The Data Register (DR) holds the operand read from memory.
The Accumulator Register (AC) is a general-purpose processing register.
The Instruction Register (IR) holds temporary data during processing.
The Temporary Register (TR) holds a temporary data during processing.
The Address Register (AR) holds a memory address and is 12 bits wide.
The Program Counter (PC) holds the address of the current instruction being executed.
Instruction words are always executed in sequence without any exceptions.
A branch instruction causes a transfer to a nonconsecutive instruction in the program.
The address part of a branch instruction is transferred to the Program Counter (PC).
To read instruction, memory read cycle is initiated, and PC is incremented by one.
The Input Register (INPR) holds an 8-bit character for an output device.
The Output Register (OUTR) receives an 8-bit character from an input device.
The Data Register (DR) holds memory operands.
The Address Register (AR) holds data for memory operations.
The Accumulator is a processor register.
The Instruction Register (IR) holds temporary data.
The Program Counter (PC) holds the address of the instruction.
The Temporary Register (TR) holds input characters.
The Input Register (INPR) holds input characters.
The Output Register (OUTR) holds output characters.
Each instruction in Mano’s Computer occupies one Memory Word.
The opcode in Mano’s Computer is 4 bits long.
The address in Mano’s Computer is 12 bits long.
Mano’s Computer can address 4K words of memory.
Mano's simple Computer uses instructions like AND, ADD, and LDA.
The text mentions 4 Instruction Code Formats.
Register-reference instructions include CLA and CMA.
Input-Output instructions include INP, OUT, ION, and SKI.
Paths must be provided to transfer information between memory and registers.
The Common Bus System is not part of the basic computer.
A common bus system is used to connect registers and memory in a computer architecture.
The common bus system in the text is described as a 32-bit bus.
The clock signal is not part of the common bus system.
The memory unit in the text has a size of 4096x16.
The common bus system includes connections to the Adder & Logic unit.
When LD (Load Input) is enabled, the particular register sends data to the bus.
Control Inputs include LD, INC, CLR, Write, and Read.
The common bus system is controlled by selection switches and enable switches.
Selection variables are used to select a register or memory whose output is used as an input to the common bus.
To select one device out of 8, we need 4 select variables.
Load input (LD) enables the input of a register to download bits from the common bus when LD = 0.
When LD = 1 for a register, the data on the common bus is read into the register.
The INR operation increments the content of a register.
The CLR operation sets the content of a register to one.
The IR register is mentioned to have 12 least significant bits.
The instruction register (IR) can be incremented or cleared.
The temporary register (TR) is accessible by external programs.
The TR can be loaded, incremented, and cleared like other registers.
The Accumulator (AC) can be shifted.
The Data Register (DR) is not involved in any operations with the Accumulator (AC).
INPR is an output device.
Memory-reference instructions have opcodes in the range 000 to 110.
When I=0 in Input-Output instructions, it indicates indirect addressing.
When I=1 in Memory-reference instructions, the opcode range is 8xxx to Exxx.
